name: Block printed bed cover B_001
description:
We bought this stunning queen size bedcover directly from the makers in Bagru village in western Rajasthan, India. They were paid a fair price.

This block printed bedcover was made by husband and wife team, Chandra Prakash and Reshma Devi. They have a keen sense of design and colour and make all their textiles in their house and dry them in the courtyard. Their designs created from multiple intricately carved wood blocks and layers of the colour reminiscent of earth and spices onto strong cotton.

Measuring a generous 222cm x 260cm, it is equally at home on the bed or thrown over the couch.
Only one in stock.

Note: any 'misprints' should be regarded as a natural part of the hand printing process and proof of the nature of this traditional craft.

To read more about the makers and the village of Bagru, go to
http://kasuemporium.wordpress.com/the-makers/the-block-printers-of-bagru-village/

10% OF THE SALE PRICE OF THIS ITEM GOES TO SOMEONE IN NEED

name: Soft pink
description:
Archival quality print by Elizabeth Spencer.

"Reminiscent of a bridal bouquet, this is actually a close up of a clover weed. You probably walk over them every day. I was delighted to discover the soft feminine shapes and colours hidden in this inconspicuous flower when peering through my macro lens."

Elizabeth is an avid photographer and loves her garden. She has combined these two passions to produce this fresh collection of spring time images.

Printed in Australia using only high quality inks on either archival quality satin photo paper or canvas, the images are produced using a process that will deliver beautiful prints that will retain their vibrancy for over 70 years!

The detailed nature of Elizabeth’s photos makes them suitable for large prints to add drama and interest to a large space, as well as smaller prints for intimate spaces. 
See below for available sizes and prices.

The images displayed here are in low resolution, but be assured that the print you receive will be in glorious high resolution. The prints are posted in a sturdy cardboard tube, ready for framing.

name: Kantha stitched vintage sari scarf   #161
description:
This delightful double sided scarf is a new item hand made from worn vintage saris using traditional Kantha stitching, still the most popular form of embroidery practised by rural women in India.

New fabrics are created from vintage saris, stitched together in tiny rows of stitches. The fabrics are placed back to back and the stitching creates a new stronger fabric with contrasting colours flashing as the cloth moves.

The stitching on the cloth gives it a slight wrinkled, wavy effect. There may be patches or tiny holes, loose threads and not so perfect edging, but this is part of the charm, and the tiny stitches hold it all together.

Truly one of a kind - this can never be repeated.
This pieces waslovingly made by women in a village near Jaipur, India.

NOTE: Free postage for this item if purchased with another product from Kasu Emporium.

name: Tribal cast bronze necklace  #2
description:
Lost wax bronze casting has been around as a tribal craft in India for about 4500 years.

Artisans in the tribal belts of the Indian states of Madhya Pradesh, Bihar, Orissa and West Bengal are still using this method to create jewellery, vessels, images of gods, goddesses, animals and birds and works from the imagination. name: The truth about Pashmina
description:
Let me introduce myself. I am Changthangi. 
I am also known as: Kashmiri or Pashmina goat.
I live in the region surrounding Ladakh in Kashmir, India. 
Humans raise my kind for meat and cashmere production and we are also used as pack animals. We are most often white but also seen in black, gray or brown and we have beautiful large twisting horns. 
Cashmere shawls have been manufactured in Nepal and Kashmir for thousands of years. The test for a quality pashmina is warmth and feel. Pashmina and Cashmere are both derived from Changthangi. One distinct difference between Pashmina and Cashmere is the fiber diameter. Pashmina fibers are finer and thinner than cashmere fiber, therefore, it is ideal for making light weight apparel like fine scarves. 

Today, however, the word PASHMINA has been used too liberally and many scarves made from natural or synthetic fiber are sold as Pashmina creating confusion in the market.

Rest assured that all the products marked as Pashmina at KASU EMPORIUM are the real deal.

name: Mirrored drawstring bag from recycled textiles    Bg #21
description:
For those who remember the 70s with a fondness for cheesecloth and embroidery, for the aging hippy, the nouveau hippy or just those who appreciate authentic tribal textiles: this is the real deal!

The ladies of western Gujarat, India, have a long tradition of embellishing their clothes with fine stitchery and mirror work.
After the costume is no longer usable, the textiles are still valued and made into these great little bags.

Cowrie shells form tassels at the four corners of the base of this gloriously decorative drawstring shoulder bag. It measures 24cm high and 28cm wide laid flat with a square inset base.

Like the lines on an old face, any 'flaws' or mends in the fabric are a testament to and a celebration of its age.

We only have a small supply of these reincarnated bags, so if you can't resist the celebration of decoration and the marks of the hands that made them, hurry to the checkout before they are all gone.

name: Hand carved wooden kitchen tools
description:
I went looking for these great tools on a recent trip to India as I have had some in my kitchen for years and they are some of my favourite things. 

I found this stock at a street market in Mussoorie, Uttarakhand in north western India and bought as many as I could fit into my small backpack.

These modest, yet great to use tools are made from Sheesham wood (also known as Indian Rosewood), a fast-growing hardwood, sourced from sustainable, government managed plantations.

Being hand-made, they vary slightly in size and shape:  
> the perforated long-handled stirrers are about 41cm long;
> the rice paddles are about 25cm long;
> the asymmetric spatulas vary in length from 23 to 28cm in  
   length.

name: Hand knitted baby elephant toys
description:
Have you always wanted your own Indian elephant?  Now's your chance to own one without any harm to widlife.  Or your could give it to a child you love, knowing that they are made from pure wool and stuffed with new cotton floss.

These little guys come from the Himalayan region of far north India in the state of Uttarakhand.  They are hand knitted from wool by artisans who receive a fair price for their work.  The colours on these cute toys are the colours of the mountains: all are made from the local vegetation and minerals.

As in nature, no two elephants are alike: each little face is a bit different: the ears curl forward or back; the eyes sleepy or awake; some are plump, others svelte; the cute striped sweaters mix and match with their owners. They stand about 12 to 14cm high: small enough to sneak into your pocket or to give to a human baby.

We have quite a herd of them in stock - too many for each to have its own mugshot, so we have grouped them into colours. The images below are an indication only. Eg: if you order a grey baby elephant, he may have a slightly different combination of colours, and the same with other colours. The colour quoted is the main body colour.

name: Bronze chameleon
description:
This mythological chameleon-like creature of indeterminate age was found in a shop in Varanasi, India. His plump body curves to a short tail, and he has short legs attached to bars with holes in them. It looks like it originally may have some practical usepurpose, but that is now a mystery. He is 11 cm long and very cute.

Dhokra bronze objects are created by the lost wax method. First a clay core is formed over which the wax is applied in layers and fine strands with intricate patterns and detail. The form is then covered in more layers of clay and left to dry in the sun or oven. The model is again heated to remove the wax and finally molten bronze is poured into the cavity, faithfully following the contours of the wax model.
The craft of dhokra bronze making dates back 4500 years and is still practiced in parts of Orissa by tribal families in villages.

name: Old tribal bronze cast woman with child
description:
We found this stunningly beautiful old dhokra bronze figure in Varanasi, India. This figure of a tribal woman carrying a child on her shoulder has the fine detail seen in older dhokra bronzes. The lady has tattoos on her face, bushy eyebrows, the nose plugs still used by some tribal women in north east India, large decorative earrings and a woven headdress with small umbrella shaped objects emerging from the back. She wears a woven bodice, layers of beads around the neck and a tiny skirt. Her legs are covered in a woven fabric and she has heavy anklets around her ankles. This solid cast figure is 19.5 cm high from her bare feet to the top of the child’s head.

name: Bronze Hanuman lock
description:
We found this very special dhokra bronze lock in a crowded and dusty antique store in Mussoorie, Uttarakhand, a northern state of India. It would probably have been used to protect a granary or other precious goods. Thought to be over 100 years old by the fine craftsmanship, this delightfully primitive rendering of the figure of Hanuman, the Monkey God, a devotee of Lord Ram.
In this figure he is accompanying his own signing on the karatal, or hand cymbals as he sings the praises of his lord. He stands 18.5cm tall from the tip of his tail to his substantial bottom. 
(NOTE: this no longer works as a lock)

name: Pashmina and wool shawl  #72
description:
Warm, soft and lightweight, this luxurious scarf/shawl is from Kullu, Himachal Pradesh in the Indian Himalayas. It is handwoven from a mixture of pashmina fibre and fine wool with a subtle herringbone weave across the naturally coloured check pattern.  
You will probably never see this quality in retail stores in the west. I have travelled to the mountains on grimy trains and rickety buses to find this treasure to present it here at Kasu. 

It measures 74 x 212cm and scrunches down into a tiny bundle when not busy keeping you warm.

The weaver of this shawl belongs to one of the oldest weaving co-operatives in India which, since 1944, has developed many benefits for its members including schools, health clinics and fair wages. The cooperative has been awarded a gold medal in a national award from the Indian Government Ministry of Textiles.

There is only one of these handsome shawls left, so hurry if you want it to be keeping you warm and stylish this winter!
